summary: Hyper-paced, high-stimulation editing style optimized for younger audiences and broad appeal through extreme visual density and rapid cuts.

core_principles.description: Relentless visual change rate prevents boredom and maintains peak stimulation
Prioritize Emotion (51%) and Story (23%) over technical continuity
VFX, green screen, explosions, large colorful subtitles create brain-stimulating aesthetic
No cuts without purpose; each must drive narrative forward or amplify emotional response
Breaths and silence eliminated, minimal frames between sentences

techniques.name: Hyper-Paced Visual Editing
techniques.description: Rapid visual changes every 1.5-3 seconds with zero tolerance for static shots
implementation: Cut or visual change every 1.5-3 seconds maximum
Use VFX, motion graphics, and green screen extensively
Quick cuts to maintain relentless energy
Punch-ins and zooms for emphasis
B-roll inserted constantly over dialogue
Music swells and drops aligned with content peaks
Colors: bright, saturated visuals
examples: Talking head (2s) → cut to reaction (1s) → b-roll (2s) → graphic (1s)
Challenge footage: rapid cuts between participants and results
Explanation: fast graphics pop in sync with speech

pros_cons.con: Can be exhausting for mature audiences
May feel formulaic or 'soulless' without genuine content

techniques.name: Rule of Six Editing Philosophy
techniques.description: Prioritize emotion and story over technical perfection in every cut decision
implementation: Cut decisions prioritized: Emotion 51%, Story 23%, other 26%
Each cut must advance emotion or story
Technical perfection secondary to emotional impact
Use cuts to create emotional arcs
Jump continuity if it serves emotion
Focus on how cut makes viewer feel
Every scene must have emotional reason for existence
examples: Cut to reaction for emotional amplification
Cut away before shot feels 'done' to maintain energy
tools: Walter Murch Rule of Six reference

pros_cons.con: Requires strong emotional understanding from editor

techniques.name: Colorful Kinetic Typography
techniques.description: Large, bold, shaking text with bright colors for maximum visibility and energy
implementation: Large, bold fonts with heavy outlines
Bright colors: yellow, green, pink, orange
Animations: shaking, rotating, scaling
Pop-in, bounce, slide animations
Words appear exactly when spoken
Text adds to energy, not just displays
Use sparingly but effectively for emphasis
techniques.timing: Synced to key words and phrases
examples: '1 MILLION DOLLARS' - bouncing bold yellow with outline
'FAIL' - red shaking text with lightning effect
tools: CapCut text effects for rapid iteration

techniques.name: SFX-Driven Pacing
techniques.description: Sound effects on every transition and emphasis point for tactile feedback
implementation: Whoosh on every cut or transition
Impact sounds on emphasis moments
Pop sounds on text appearances
Swishes on camera movements
Layer SFX to match visual intensity
Use sound design to heighten impact
Sync SFX perfectly to visual frame accuracy
techniques.timing: Synced to every transition and emphasis
examples: Money reveal: cash register or impact sound
Winner announcement: triumph sound with swelling music
tools: SFX libraries with whooshes and impacts

techniques.name: High-Energy Music Integration
techniques.description: Background music tracks that maintain high energy throughout with strategic drops
implementation: Select upbeat, high-energy music throughout
Music peaks aligned with content climaxes
Music drops on key revelations or jokes
Use music swells before big reveals
Maintain engaging rhythm throughout
Avoid music that feels background-y
Music contributes to overall energy level
examples: Buildup with rising music → reveal with drop
Climax: music swells to maximum energy

pros_cons.con: May overwhelm delicate content if not balanced
High-energy music can become fatiguing in long videos
